title: The for Loop (When You Know the Count)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you need to write 'I will not talk in class' 100 times on the blackboard. You wouldn't write it once and think 'okay, done!' - you'd repeat it exactly 100 times.

That's what a FOR LOOP does! It repeats code a SPECIFIC number of times. You tell it:
1. Where to start (I'm starting at line 1)
2. When to stop (Keep going until I reach line 100)
3. How to count (Add 1 each time)

Think of it like a countdown: '10, 9, 8, 7...' or a count-up: '1, 2, 3, 4...'. The for loop handles the counting FOR you!

The for loop is PERFECT when you know EXACTLY how many times to repeat. Need to process 50 items? Use a for loop counting from 0 to 49. Need to print numbers 1 to 10? For loop!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Three parts separated by semicolons: 1) Start point (int i = 0), 2) When to stop (i < 10), 3) How to change i each time (i++)
INITIALIZATION: Creates a counter variable (usually called i, j, or k). This runs ONCE at the start. i typically starts at 0 or 1.
CONDITION: Checked BEFORE each loop. If true, the loop runs. If false, the loop stops. Here: 'keep going while i is 5 or less'.
INCREMENT: Runs AFTER each loop iteration. i++ adds 1 to i. Could also be i--, i += 2, etc. This moves you closer to the end!
The code in braces runs each time. If the loop runs 5 times, this code executes 5 times with different values of i!

challenge.instructions:
Create a program that displays a countdown for a rocket launch!

1. Use a for loop to count down from 10 to 1
2. Display each number
3. After the loop ends, display 'Liftoff!'

Bonus: Try making it count from 20 to 1, or count by 2s!
challenge.hint: Start at 10: int i = 10. Keep going while i >= 1. Count down: i--. Structure: for (int i = 10; i >= 1; i--) { }
commonStickingPoints: Using commas instead of semicolons: for (int i = 0, i < 10, i++) is WRONG! Use semicolons: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)
Infinite loops from wrong condition: for (int i = 0; i >= 0; i++) never ends because i is ALWAYS >= 0! Make sure your condition eventually becomes false.
Off-by-one errors: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) runs 10 times (0-9). for (int i = 0; i <= 10; i++) runs 11 times (0-10)!
Forgetting the increment: for (int i = 0; i < 10; ) with no i++ creates an infinite loop! i never changes so i < 10 is always true.
